title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, confidentiality, and program administration. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Speaker appoints three members, including academic researchers, data experts, and individuals with experience in program administration. The Minority Leader appoints three members, including academic researchers and data experts. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints 6 members, with 3 appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives and 3 appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate. Each group includes 2 academic researchers/data experts and 1 expert in database management and privacy. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints 6 members, with 3 appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives and 3 appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate. Each group includes 2 academic researchers/data experts and 1 expert in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints 6 members with expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, and database management. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives selects the co-chairperson. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints 6 members with expertise in various fields. The chairperson and co-chairperson are selected by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, respectively. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses. Members of the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses for their services. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and statistical protocols for Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating administrative data for program evaluation and research. The Commission will make recommendations on integrating data series for program evaluation and research, modifying data infrastructure, and incorporating outcomes measurement into program design. The Commission will make recommendations on incorporating outcomes measurement, randomized controlled trials, and impact analysis into program design. They will also consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, including relevant administrative datasets and potential linkages with survey datasets. The potential clearinghouse for program evaluation and Federal policy-making should include survey datasets and administrative datasets. Legal and administrative barriers to data inclusion and linking should be addressed, along with determining the data-sharing infrastructure for research access. Self-funding options, access criteria for researchers and institutions, and data merging methods should also be considered. The potential clearinghouse for program evaluation and Federal policy-making should include survey and administrative datasets. Considerations include self-funding, access criteria for researchers, data merging methods, limitations on data use, privacy protection, and using research results to inform program design and policy decisions. Incentives for interagency information sharing to enhance program effectiveness should also be explored. The Commission will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions based on the study. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions based on the study, including a definition of "administrative data." The report deadline is 15 months after a majority of Commission members are appointed. The Commission members are appointed according to section 3. "Administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency for a Federal program, including various measures and indicators as defined in title 31, United States Code. The Commission operates according to section 5 and has specific powers. The Commission operates according to section 5 and has specific powers. Administrative Assistance: Heads of various agencies advise and consult with the Commission on matters within their areas of responsibility. Agencies include Office of Management and Budget, Bureau of the Census, Internal Revenue Service, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Agriculture, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Social Security Administration, Department of Education, and Department of Justice. The Commission, as determined by the Commission, shall meet within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members and as scheduled by the chairperson. The chairperson and co-chairperson, with majority approval, establish rules of procedure. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Written rules of procedure, including a quorum requirement, will be established by the chairperson and co-chairperson with majority approval. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, contract with government and private agencies, use the United States mails, and accept gifts or donations. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails, accept gifts or donations, and contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for administration. Funding is provided by principal statistical agencies upon request from the Director of the Census. The National Academy of Public Administration administers the Commission, with funding provided by principal statistical agencies not exceeding $2,000,000. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson with the concurrence of the co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services as needed. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants as needed, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a comparable position under the General Schedule. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
